channel.title: JaneBytes Cybersecurity Feed
channel.description: Summarized articles from top cybersecurity sources.

item.title: Hacker sneaks infostealer malware into early access Steam game
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Aether Forge Studios, Chemia; CVE(s): None; Summary: EncryptHub compromised the Chemia game files on Steam to distribute info-stealing malware, specifically HijackLoader and Fickle Stealer. The malware was distributed through a DLL file and PowerShell script, which harvested data stored in web browsers.

item.title: Mitel warns of critical MiVoice MX-ONE authentication bypass flaw
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Mitel Networks MiVoice MX-ONE; CVE(s): None; Summary: The MiVoice MX-ONE Provisioning Manager component contains an improper access control weakness that allows unauthenticated attackers to gain unauthorized access to administrator accounts on unpatched systems, which can be exploited in low-complexity attacks without user interaction.

item.title: CastleLoader Malware Infects 469 Devices Using Fake GitHub Repos and ClickFix Phishing
item.description: CastleLoader is a versatile malware loader used to distribute various information stealers and remote access trojans (RATs). It employs dead code injection, packing techniques, and anti-analysis measures to hinder analysis. The loader connects to a C2 server, downloads target modules, and executes them, making it a primary distribution mechanism in the current threat landscape.

item.title: Elephant APT Group Exploits VLC Player and Encrypted Shellcode in Attacks on Defense Sector
item.description: The article reports a sophisticated cyber-espionage operation attributed to the Dropping Elephant APT group, targeting Turkish defense contractors specializing in precision-guided missile systems. The campaign involves spear-phishing emails with malicious LNK files, DLL side-loading techniques, and shellcode injection using QueueUserAPC.

item.title: Threat Actors Using .hwp Files to Distribute RokRAT Malware and Evade Detection Mechanisms
item.description: The AhnLab Security Intelligence Center (ASEC) discovered a sophisticated campaign using Hangul Word Processor (.hwp) documents to spread the RokRAT remote access trojan (RAT). The malware uses Object Linking and Embedding (OLE) objects, DLL side-loading, and steganographic analysis to evade security detections and execute arbitrary code.

item.title: Sophos and SonicWall Patch Critical RCE Flaws Affecting Firewalls and SMA 100 Devices
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Sophos Firewall; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6704 (CVSS score: 9.8), CVE-2025-7624 (CVSS score: 9.8), CVE-2025-7382 (CVSS score: 8.8); Summary: Two vulnerabilities in Sophos Firewall, including arbitrary file writing and SQL injection flaws, can lead to remote code execution. Additionally, a high-severity command injection vulnerability in the WebAdmin component can result in pre-auth code execution on High Availability auxiliary devices.

item.title: Bloomberg Comdb2 null pointer dereference and denial-of-service vulnerabilities
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Bloomberg Comdb2; CVE(s): TALOS-2025-2197 (CVE-2025-36520), TALOS-2025-2201 (CVE-2025-35966), TALOS-2025-2199 (CVE-2025-48498), TALOS-2025-2198 (CVE-2025-46354), TALOS-2025-2200 (CVE-2025-36512); Summary: Three null pointer dereference vulnerabilities exist in Bloomberg Comdb2 8.1, which can lead to denial of service by sending crafted messages over TCP. Additionally, there are two denial-of-service vulnerabilities in the Distributed Transaction Commit/Abort Operation and database handling a distributed transaction heartbeat.

item.title: ZDI-25-646: Amazon AWS Client VPN Uncontrolled Search Path Element Local Privilege Escalation Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Amazon AWS Client VPN; CVE(s): CVE-2025-8069; Summary: This vulnerability allows local attackers to escalate privileges on affected installations of Amazon AWS Client VPN by exploiting an uncontrolled search path element in the OpenSSL configuration. The attacker must first obtain low-privileged code execution to exploit this vulnerability, which can be used to execute arbitrary code in the context of SYSTEM.

item.title: NoName057(16) Hackers Target 3,700 Unique Devices Over the Last 13 Months
item.description: This article is about the NoName057(16) hacktivist collective, which has been executing distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks against government and public-sector entities in European nations. The group uses a volunteer-driven platform called DDoSia to orchestrate large-scale application-layer DDoS campaigns.

item.title: Hackers breach Toptal GitHub account, publish malicious npm packages
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Toptal's GitHub organization account; CVE(s): None; Summary: Hackers compromised Toptal's GitHub organization account and used their access to publish ten malicious packages on the Node Package Manager (NPM) index. The packages included data-stealing code that collected GitHub authentication tokens and then wiped the victims' systems.

item.title: UNC3944 Exploits VMware vSphere to Deploy Ransomware and Steal Data from Organizations
item.description: This article discusses a highly advanced cyber operation orchestrated by the threat actor UNC3944, which uses social engineering tactics to infiltrate organizations and conduct reconnaissance on internal resources. The group exploits VMware vSphere environments, using a "living-off-the-land" methodology to minimize detectable indicators of compromise.

item.title: Splunk Guide to Detect, Mitigate, and Respond to the CitrixBleed 2 Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Citrix NetScaler ADC and Gateway devices; CVE(s): CVE-2025-5777; Summary: An out-of-bounds memory read vulnerability (CVE-2025-5777) affects Citrix NetScaler ADC and Gateway devices, enabling unauthenticated attackers to leak sensitive memory contents via malformed HTTP POST requests. The vulnerability has a CVSS score of 9.3 and is exploited through simple payloads like an incomplete "login" parameter.

item.title: Medtronic MyCareLink Patient Monitor
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Medtronic MyCareLink Patient Monitor 24950 and 24952; CVE(s): CVE-2025-4393, CVE-2025-4394, CVE-2025-4395; Summary: Successful exploitation of these vulnerabilities could lead to system compromise, unauthorized access to sensitive data, and manipulation of the monitor's functionality. The vulnerabilities are due to cleartext storage of sensitive information, an empty password in a configuration file, and deserialization of untrusted data.

item.title: CISA Releases Six Industrial Control Systems Advisories
item.description: The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) released six Industrial Control Systems (ICS) advisories on July 24, 2025, providing information about current security issues, vulnerabilities, and exploits surrounding ICS. These advisories are intended for users and administrators to review technical details and mitigations.

item.title: Mitsubishi Electric CNC Series
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Mitsubishi Electric CNC Series; CVE(s): CVE-2016-2542; Summary: The vulnerability allows an attacker to execute malicious code by getting setup-launcher to load a malicious DLL due to Uncontrolled Search Path Element (CWE-427). Successful exploitation could lead to the execution of malicious code.

item.title: Network Thermostat X-Series WiFi Thermostats
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Network Thermostat X-Series WiFi thermostats; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6260; Summary: The vulnerable embedded web server allows unauthenticated attackers to gain direct access, reset user credentials, and potentially gain full administrative access. This vulnerability can be exploited remotely with low attack complexity.

item.title: LG Innotek Camera Model LNV5110R
item.description: Vulnerable Product: LG Innotek Camera Model LNV5110R; CVE(s): CVE-2025-7742; Summary: An authentication vulnerability exists in the camera model's firmware, allowing a malicious actor to upload an HTTP POST request to the device's non-volatile storage and potentially gain administrative access. Successful exploitation could lead to remote code execution at the administrator privilege level.

item.title: Honeywell Experion PKS
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Honeywell Experion PKS; CVE(s): CVE-2025-2520, CVE-2025-2521, CVE-2025-2522, CVE-2025-3946, CVE-2025-3947; Summary: The Honeywell Experion PKS contains multiple vulnerabilities including uninitialized variables, memory buffer issues, sensitive information reuse, integer underflows, and wrong handler deployments. Successful exploitation could lead to information exposure, denial of service, or remote code execution.

item.title: Watch This Webinar to Uncover Hidden Flaws in Login, AI, and Digital Trust — and Fix Them
item.description: The article discusses the importance of managing customer logins and data privacy in the era of AI. It highlights the need for organizations to adapt their identity strategies to keep pace with changing user expectations and emerging threats. The webinar "Navigating Customer Identity in the AI Era" offers insights from Auth0's 2025 CIAM Trends Report, providing attendees with practical advice on navigating these challenges.

item.title: SonicWall urges admins to patch critical RCE flaw in SMA 100 devices
item.description: Vulnerable Product: SonicWall SMA 100 series appliances; CVE(s): CVE-2025-40599; Summary: The SMA 100 series appliances contain a critical authenticated arbitrary file upload vulnerability that can allow remote threat actors to gain code execution. Attackers need admin privileges to exploit this vulnerability, but SonicWall has not found evidence of active exploitation.

item.title: Pentests once a year? Nope. It’s time to build an offensive SOC
item.description: The article discusses the importance of having an ongoing and dynamic approach to offensive security, rather than relying on periodic pentests or audits. It argues that traditional approaches are insufficient in today's rapidly changing threat landscape and introduces the concept of an "Offensive Security Operations Center" (OSOC) as a solution. The OSOC would continuously validate exposures across prevention, detection, and response layers, using tools such as Breach and Attack Simulation (BAS) and Automated Penetration Testing.

item.title: China-Based APTs Deploy Fake Dalai Lama Apps to Spy on Tibetan Community
item.description: A China-nexus cyber espionage group has been targeting the Tibetan community with two campaigns (Operation GhostChat and Operation PhantomPrayers) ahead of the Dalai Lama's 90th birthday. The attacks use watering hole techniques, compromising legitimate websites and installing backdoors on victim systems to gather sensitive information.

item.title: Researchers Exploit Cursor Background Agents to Take Over Amazon EC2 Instance
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Cursor's Background Agents; CVE(s): None; Summary: The article discusses a vulnerability in Cursor's Background Agents that allows unauthorized access to an Amazon EC2 instance. The vulnerability is exploited through the "Show Terminal" button, which provides direct command-line access to the remote infrastructure. The researchers gain root access and can execute commands on the compromised machine, highlighting potential risks for privilege escalation and malicious activities such as cryptocurrency mining or data exfiltration.

item.title: Storm-2603 Exploits SharePoint Flaws to Deploy Warlock Ransomware on Unpatched Systems
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft SharePoint Server; CVE(s): CVE-2025-49706, CVE-2025-49704; Summary: The article discusses a vulnerability in on-premises Microsoft SharePoint Server that allows attackers to deploy Warlock ransomware. The attack chain involves exploiting two vulnerabilities (CVE-2025-49706 and CVE-2025-49704) to gain initial access, conduct lateral movement, and ultimately deploy the ransomware.

item.title: Unmasking the new Chaos RaaS group attacks
item.description:
FYSA:
The provided article appears to be an analysis of the Chaos ransomware group's tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs). The article highlights the similarities between the Chaos ransomware and other notable groups such as BlackSuit (Royal) ransomware. It also provides details on how the malware works, including its encryption methods and cleanup procedures.
Some key points from the article include:
1. The Chaos ransomware uses hybrid cryptographic techniques, combining Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman (ECDH) with Curve25519 for asymmetric operations and AES-256 for symmetric file encryption. 2. The ransomware performs selective encryption based on command-line configuration parameters, allowing operators to customize the attack. 3. The malware targets local and network resources, using SMB connections to encrypt shared drives and distributed file systems. 4. The article provides details on how the Chaos ransomware can be detected and blocked by various Cisco products, including Secure Endpoint, Secure Email, Secure Firewall, and others.
Overall, this article appears to be a comprehensive analysis of the Chaos ransomware group's TTPs, highlighting their similarities with other notable groups and providing insights into how they operate.

item.title: AI-Driven Wi-Fi Biometrics WhoFi Tracks Humans Behind Walls with 95.5% Accuracy
item.description: This article introduces WhoFi, an AI-powered deep learning pipeline that uses Wi-Fi Channel State Information (CSI) for person re-identification (Re-ID), achieving high accuracy on the NTU-Fi dataset. The system's robustness and privacy features make it suitable for applications in smart environments, such as security systems and healthcare monitoring.

item.title: Microsoft: SharePoint servers also targeted in ransomware attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft SharePoint; CVE(s): CVE-2025-49706, CVE-2025-49704, CVE-2025-53770; Summary: A China-based hacking group is exploiting a zero-day exploit chain on Microsoft SharePoint servers, leading to widespread attacks. The attackers use Mimikatz to extract plaintext credentials, move laterally with PsExec and Impacket, and deliver Warlock ransomware across compromised systems.

item.title: Chinese Hackers Launch Targeted Campaign to Infect Windows Systems with Ghost RAT and PhantomNet Malware
item.description: A China-nexus advanced persistent threat (APT) group attributed to Operation GhostChat and Operation PhantomPrayers targeted the Tibetan community by compromising legitimate websites and distributing trojanized software. The attacks employed advanced evasion techniques, including DLL sideloading, shellcode injection, and encrypted payloads to bypass endpoint detection and response solutions.

item.title: Google Introduces OSS Rebuild to Boost Security in Open-Source Package Ecosystems
item.description: Vulnerable Product: None; Summary: This article is about Google's OSS Rebuild project, which aims to enhance trust in package registries by independently reproducing upstream artifacts and generating SLSA Provenance attestations that meet Build Level 3 requirements. The project targets supply chain attacks on widely-used dependencies across Python's PyPI, JavaScript/TypeScript's npm, and Rust's Crates.io.

item.title: Metasploit Module Released to Exploit SharePoint 0-Day Vulnerabilities
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft SharePoint Server; CVE(s): CVE-2025-53770, CVE-2025-53771; Summary: The Metasploit module exploits a chain of unauthenticated remote code execution flaws in Microsoft SharePoint Server, allowing attackers to achieve complete system compromise without requiring authentication. The vulnerabilities represent sophisticated patch bypasses and can be exploited through the _/layouts/15/ToolPane.aspx endpoint, potentially leading to data theft, ransomware deployment, and lateral movement within corporate networks.

item.title: TP-Link Network Video Recorder Vulnerability Enables Arbitrary Command Execution
item.description: Vulnerable Product: TP-Link VIGI Network Video Recorder models (VIGI NVR1104H-4P V1 and VIGI NVR2016H-16MP V2); CVE(s): CVE-2025-7723, CVE-2025-7724; Summary: The two TP-Link VIGI network video recorder models have critical security vulnerabilities that allow attackers to execute arbitrary commands on the underlying operating system. The flaws are characterized as authenticated and unauthenticated OS command injection vulnerabilities with high CVSS scores of 8.5 and 8.7, respectively.

item.title: Europol Arrests XSS Forum Admin in Kyiv After 12-Year Run Operating Cybercrime Marketplace
item.description: Europol has arrested the suspected administrator of XSS.is, a Russian-speaking cybercrime platform, in collaboration with Ukrainian authorities and French Police. The platform, which had over 50,000 registered users, served as a marketplace for stolen data, hacking tools, and illicit services. The suspect is estimated to have made €7 million in profits from advertising and facilitation fees.

item.title: Weidmueller Industrial Routers Exposed to Remote Code Execution Flaws
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Weidmueller Industrial Routers (IE-SR-2TX); CVE(s): VDE-2025-052, None; Summary: Five high-severity security vulnerabilities in Weidmueller's IE-SR-2TX router series allow attackers to execute arbitrary code with root privileges, potentially compromising industrial networks and critical infrastructure. The flaws impact several models of wireless security routers commonly deployed in these environments.

item.title: AWS Client VPN for Windows Vulnerability Could Allow Privilege Escalation
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Amazon Web Services (AWS) Client VPN; CVE(s): CVE-2025-8069; Summary: The AWS Client VPN software for Windows contains a critical vulnerability that allows non-administrative users to escalate their privileges to root-level access during the installation process. The flaw is due to a design error in the installation process, which can be exploited by placing arbitrary code within the OpenSSL configuration file. An attacker with elevated privileges could then use this code to gain unauthorized access to the system.

item.title: GitLab Publishes Security Update Addressing Several Vulnerabilities in Community and Enterprise Edition
item.description: Vulnerable Product: GitLab; CVE(s): CVE-2025-4700, CVE-2025-4439, CVE-2025-7001, CVE-2025-4976; Summary: GitLab has released critical security patches addressing six vulnerabilities across its Community Edition (CE) and Enterprise Edition (EE) platforms. The most severe issues are two high-severity cross-site scripting (XSS) flaws that could allow unauthorized access to sensitive information and enable malicious script execution in specific deployment scenarios.

item.title: SonicWall SMA 100 Vulnerabilities Allow Remote Execution of Arbitrary JavaScript
item.description: Vulnerable Product: SonicWall SMA 100 series appliances; CVE(s): CVE-2025-40596, CVE-2025-40597, and CVE-2025-40598; Summary: The vulnerabilities allow unauthenticated remote attackers to trigger denial-of-service conditions or execute arbitrary code and JavaScript. Two buffer overflow issues can crash the appliance or execute arbitrary code, while a reflected cross-site scripting vulnerability allows an attacker to inject malicious JavaScript into unsuspecting user sessions.

item.title: CISA Alerts on Google Chromium Input Validation Flaw Actively Exploited
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Google Chromium; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6558; Summary: A severe input validation vulnerability in Google Chromium's ANGLE and GPU components allows remote attackers to execute sandbox escape attacks through specially crafted HTML pages, affecting millions of users across multiple web browsers.

item.title: Hackers Deploy Stealth Backdoor in WordPress Mu-Plugins to Maintain Admin Access
item.description: Vulnerable Product: WordPress; CVE(s): None; Summary: A stealthy backdoor has been discovered in WordPress's "mu-plugins" directory, allowing threat actors to gain persistent access and perform arbitrary actions. The backdoor injects a file manager into the theme directory, creates an administrator user, downloads a malicious plugin, and changes passwords to lock out other administrators.

item.title: Brave blocks Windows Recall from screenshotting your browsing activity
item.description: Brave Browser has blocked Microsoft's Windows Recall feature from capturing screenshots of its windows by default, to protect users' privacy. This was done by utilizing Microsoft's SetInputScope API and setting the input scope to IS_PRIVATE for all browser windows.

item.title: What to know about ToolShell, the SharePoint threat under mass exploitation
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft SharePoint; CVE(s): CVE-2025-49706, CVE-2025-49704; Summary: The vulnerability allows attackers to infect systems with a webshell-based backdoor that gains access to sensitive parts of the SharePoint Server. Attackers can then extract tokens and credentials, gain administrative privileges, and exfiltrate sensitive data and deploy additional backdoors for future use.

item.title: After $380M hack, Clorox sues its “service desk” vendor for simply giving out passwords
item.description: Clorox's internal password reset tool, MyID, and Okta passwords were compromised by a cybercriminal posing as an employee. The attacker successfully reset passwords and obtained MFA resets from Cognizant agents without proper verification procedures being followed.

item.title: Proton launches privacy-respecting encrypted AI assistant Lumo
item.description: Proton has launched Lumo, a privacy-first AI assistant that does not log user conversations and doesn't use their prompts for training. The tool uses open-source large language models and encryption scheme, with complete source code available. It supports file uploads with full encryption support and is available on Android and iOS devices.

item.title: Hackers fooled Cognizant help desk, says Clorox in $380M cyberattack lawsuit
item.description: Clorox is suing Cognizant for gross negligence after a massive August 2023 cyberattack, allegedly enabled by Cognizant's failure to verify the identity of an employee whose password was reset by hackers without proper authentication. The incident gave attackers privileged access to Clorox's IT network, resulting in business disruption and losses.

item.title: Threat Actor Mimo Targets Magento and Docker to Deploy Crypto Miners and Proxyware
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: Magento CMS; CVE(s): None; Summary: Mimo, a threat actor, exploits undetermined PHP-FPM vulnerabilities in Magento e-commerce installations to obtain initial access and then uses GSocket to establish persistent access. The vulnerability allows command injection via a Magento CMS plugin.
FYSA: A threat actor known as Mimo has shifted its tactics from targeting vulnerable Craft CMS instances to exploiting Magento CMS and misconfigured Docker instances, ultimately deploying cryptocurrency miners and proxyware to monetize compromised machines' CPU resources and unused internet bandwidth.

item.title: ChatGPT is rolling out 'personality' toggles to become your assistant
item.description: The article discusses the rollout of a new "personality" feature on OpenAI's ChatGPT web app, allowing users to personalize how ChatGPT interacts with them. The feature includes multiple personalities such as "Robot," "Cynic," "Listener," and "Sage."

item.title: Hidden Backdoor in WordPress Plugins Grants Attackers Ongoing Access to Websites
item.description: Vulnerable Product: WordPress; CVE(s): None; Summary: A highly skilled malware campaign targets WordPress websites by inserting a covert backdoor in the mu-plugins directory, allowing for persistent threats and unrestricted administrator privileges. The malware loads remote payloads, executes arbitrary PHP code, and creates hidden administrator accounts, making it resilient to standard remediation efforts.

item.title: Operation CargoTalon Targets Russian Aerospace & Defense to Deploy EAGLET Implant
item.description: This article discusses Operation CargoTalon, a sophisticated spear-phishing campaign targeting employees at Russia's Voronezh Aircraft Production Association (VASO). The campaign uses malicious attachments and DLL files to deliver an EAGLET payload with espionage-focused features.

item.title: NPM package ‘is’ with 2.8M weekly downloads infected devs with malware
item.description: Vulnerable Product: John Harband 'is'; CVE(s): None; Summary: The 'is' NPM package was compromised in a supply chain attack that injected backdoor malware, allowing attackers to gain full access to compromised devices. Maintainer accounts were hijacked via phishing, and unauthorized owner changes went unnoticed for several hours, potentially compromising many developers who downloaded the new releases.

item.title: US nuclear weapons agency hacked in Microsoft SharePoint attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft SharePoint; CVE(s): None (zero-day vulnerability); Summary: Unknown threat actors exploited a recently patched Microsoft SharePoint zero-day vulnerability chain, breaching the National Nuclear Security Administration's network and potentially compromising 148 organizations worldwide.

item.title: US nuclear weapons agency reportedly hacked in SharePoint attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft SharePoint; CVE(s): CVE-2025-53770, "None"; Summary: A zero-day vulnerability chain (ToolShell) in Microsoft SharePoint was exploited to breach the National Nuclear Security Administration's network and compromise at least 148 organizations worldwide. The vulnerability is being used by Chinese state-sponsored hacking groups.

item.title: Clorox Files Lawsuit Against Cognizant Over Employee Password Leak to Hackers
item.description: Clorox is suing Cognizant for $380 million over a cyberattack that allegedly occurred when Cognizant employees handed over network credentials to a criminal pretending to be a Clorox employee. The lawsuit claims Cognizant's security failures enabled the attack, which resulted in significant damages and disruptions to Clorox's operations.

item.title: New ACRStealer Exploits Google Docs and Steam for C2 Server Using DDR Technique
item.description: ACRStealer is an infostealer malware that continues to evolve and evade detection by introducing new features such as bypassing traditional monitoring tools, maintaining core information theft capabilities, and facilitating the installation of supplementary malware strains. The threat actors behind ACRStealer have incorporated techniques like Heaven's Gate and manual HTTP structure assembly to disrupt dynamic analysis and signature-based detection.

item.title: OpenAI confirms ChatGPT's new study feature, helps with exams
item.description: OpenAI is testing a new feature, "Study Together", within the ChatGPT web app, allowing users to get homework help or break down complex problems with step-by-step guides. The feature will roll out to everyone in the coming hours or days. Additionally, OpenAI's Codex and Sora 2 projects are also mentioned, along with plans for a ChatGPT product by 2026 and a price drop for the ChatGPT o3 API.

item.title: How to harden your Active Directory against Kerberoasting
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Active Directory; CVE(s): None; Summary: Kerberoasting is a privilege escalation attack that targets service accounts with Service Principle Names (SPNs) in Active Directory, allowing attackers to compromise service accounts with low risk of detection. The attack involves exploiting an existing Windows user account, requesting a service ticket from the Ticket Granting Service, and then cracking the SPN password hash using brute force techniques.

item.title: Mimo Targets Magento CMS to Steal Card Details and Monetize Bandwidth
item.description: The Mimo threat actor has been observed expanding its operations from Craft CMS to Magento CMS, exploiting undetermined PHP-FPM flaws to gain initial access. This evolution includes sophisticated persistence and evasion mechanisms, suggesting preparation for more advanced financial crimes beyond mere resource exploitation.

item.title: OpenAI prepares Sora 2 to take on Google's Veo 3
item.description: OpenAI is working on Sora 2, a successor to their generative video model Sora, while Google has announced Veo 3 is free for college students with the Gemini AI Pro plan. The article also mentions ChatGPT's GPT-5-reasoning-alpha and o3-alpha models, which may have implications for education and coding.

item.title: Ukraine arrests suspected admin of XSS Russian hacking forum
item.description: The suspected administrator of a Russian-speaking hacking forum XSS.is was arrested by Ukrainian authorities at the request of the Paris public prosecutor's office, amid an investigation into ransomware and cybercrimes. This development is likely to have a chilling effect on the activity at XSS, as users fearing exposure to law enforcement may turn to other sites. The arrest comes shortly after French police arrested five operators of another major cybercrime platform, BreachForum.

item.title: CISA warns of hackers exploiting SysAid vulnerabilities in attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: SysAid IT service management (ITSM) software; CVE(s): CVE-2025-2775, CVE-2025-2776; Summary: Two unauthenticated XML External Entity (XXE) flaws allow attackers to hijack administrator accounts and retrieve local files containing sensitive information. The vulnerabilities were patched in March 2024 with the release of SysAid On-Prem version 24.4.60, but attacks are still ongoing.

item.title: Silicon Valley Engineer Pleads Guilty in U.S. Missile Detection Data Theft Case
item.description: This article is not about a vulnerability, but rather an instance of economic espionage and technology theft. A Silicon Valley engineer, Chenguang Gong, pleaded guilty to stealing critical defense technologies worth hundreds of millions of dollars from a Los Angeles-area research and development company. The stolen data included blueprints for sophisticated sensors and countermeasure technologies designed for military applications.

item.title: npm 'accidentally' removes Stylus package, breaks builds and pipelines
item.description: The article reports that npm mistakenly took down the Stylus library, a legitimate package receiving 3 million weekly downloads, and replaced it with a security holding page. This was due to an administrative error involving one of the maintainers, who had published malicious packages in the past.

item.title: Cyberattack on Germany’s AMEOS Hospital Network Exposes Patient Data
item.description: The article reports a cyberattack on Germany's AMEOS Hospital Network, which resulted in unauthorized access and potential exposure of sensitive data. Despite robust defenses, attackers managed to infiltrate the network using advanced persistent threat (APT) tactics, potentially exfiltrating personal health information, employee records, and partner data.

item.title: New Coyote Malware Variant Exploits Windows UI Automation to Steal Banking Credentials
item.description: The Windows banking trojan Coyote exploits the Windows accessibility framework UI Automation (UIA) to harvest sensitive information, targeting Brazilian users by extracting credentials linked to 75 banking institutes' web addresses and cryptocurrency exchanges. The malware uses UIA to parse through UI child elements of windows in an attempt to identify browser tabs or address bars and cross-reference with a list of targeted addresses.

item.title: US Nuclear Weapons Data Compromised via SharePoint Zero-Day Attack
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft SharePoint; CVE(s): None; Summary: A zero-day exploit in Microsoft SharePoint was linked to Chinese government-affiliated hacking groups, compromising critical US government infrastructure, including the National Nuclear Security Administration. The vulnerability allowed hackers to remotely access SharePoint servers, enabling data theft and potential movement across connected services.

item.title: Malicious LNK File Posing as Credit Card Security Email Steals User Data
item.description: Threat actors have deployed a malicious LNK file masquerading as a credit card company's security email authentication pop-up to pilfer sensitive user information. The LNK file executes alongside a decoy file, fetching an additional HTA and bait HTML document from the attacker's server, storing and running them in the system's temporary folder. The malware exhibits specialized infostealer and backdoor capabilities, targeting browser data from multiple browsers and services, as well as executing remote shell commands and exfiltrating documents.

item.title: Lumma Stealer Masquerades as Pirated Apps to Steal Logins and Data
item.description: This article is not about a vulnerability. It discusses the resurgence of Lumma Stealer, an information-stealing malware-as-a-service platform, after a global law enforcement operation in May 2025. The malware has evolved and adapted to evade detection, using various tactics such as domain obfuscation, cloud-based providers, and social engineering.

item.title: Synology BeeDrive for Desktop on Windows Vulnerabilities Let Hackers Run Malicious Code
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Synology BeeDrive desktop application for Windows; CVE(s): CVE-2025-54158, CVE-2025-54159, CVE-2025-54160; Summary: The BeeDrive desktop application for Windows contains three critical vulnerabilities that allow attackers to execute malicious code, delete arbitrary files, and gain elevated privileges. The flaws can be exploited using local or remote attack vectors, making them a significant risk to system integrity and data security.

item.title: New ZuRu Malware Variant Targets macOS via Termius SSH Exploit
item.description: The article discusses a variant of the macOS.ZuRu malware that has resurfaced, employing advanced evasion techniques to deploy a modified Khepri command-and-control beacon. The malware uses trojanized versions of SSH client Termius and other backend tools like SecureCRT and Navicat to infiltrate professional workflows.

item.title: Windows 11 Introduces Powerful New AI Features – What’s New!
item.description: This article is about the new AI-powered features and enhancements in Windows 11, including a conversational agent in the Settings app, improved search, productivity tools, and features like Relight and object select tool in Paint. The update aims to make PCs smarter, more responsive, and better tailored to individual needs.

item.title: Brave Browser Block Microsoft Recall Over Privacy Issues
item.description: Microsoft's Recall feature, which periodically captures full-screen snapshots of user activity, was criticized for its potential to expose sensitive browsing habits through an unencrypted, local database. Brave Software has proactively disabled Recall by default in its browser starting with version 1.81 for Windows 11 and newer.

item.title: Operator of Jetflix illegal streaming service gets 7 years in prison
item.description: The article discusses the conviction of Kristopher Lee Dallmann, the ringleader of the illegal paid streaming operation Jetflicks, which operated for 12 years and had tens of thousands of subscribers. The scheme generated millions of dollars in criminal profits by pirating content from platforms like Netflix, Hulu, Vudu, and Amazon Prime.

item.title: Critical JavaScript Library Vulnerability Exposes Apps to Remote Attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: form-data JavaScript package; CVE(s): CVE-2025-7783; Summary: The form-data JavaScript package contains a critical vulnerability that allows attackers to predict and manipulate boundary values in multipart form-encoded data. This can lead to parameter injection attacks, compromising internal systems and exposing sensitive data.

item.title: Kerberoasting Detections: A New Approach to a Decade-Old Challenge
item.description: This article discusses the challenges of detecting Kerberoasting attacks, which exploit weaknesses in Kerberos authentication protocol. It highlights the limitations of traditional heuristic-based detection methods and proposes a statistical framework for improving anomaly detection accuracy and reducing false positives. The article presents a model that groups similar ticket-request patterns into distinct clusters and uses histogram bins to track frequency over time, allowing for more accurate identification of anomalies.

item.title: Microsoft fixes bug behind incorrect Windows Firewall errors
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft; CVE(s): None; Summary: A known issue in Windows 11 24H2 systems with the June 2025 preview update installed triggers invalid Windows Firewall errors after rebooting. The bug has been fixed in the KB5062660preview cumulative update for Windows 11 24H2, released on Tuesday, and will be generally available to all users who install the August Patch Tuesday updates.

item.title: Meet Hazel Burton
item.description: This article is not about a vulnerability or cybersecurity-relevant content. It appears to be an employee spotlight or "Humans of Talos" series featuring Hazel Burton, a team member at Talos. The conversation touches on her career journey and what drew her to join the organization, as well as her advice for someone looking to join Talos.

item.title: Google Launches OSS Rebuild to Expose Malicious Code in Widely Used Open-Source Packages
item.description: Google's OSS Rebuild initiative aims to bolster the security of open-source package ecosystems by providing build provenance for packages across various registries. It leverages automation, heuristics, and network monitoring capabilities to produce trustworthy security metadata, enabling users to verify a package's origin and detect supply chain compromises.

item.title: Coyote Malware Targets WILS, Abusing Microsoft UI Automation to Exfiltrate Logins
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft UI Automation (UIA) framework; CVE(s): None; Summary: A novel variant of the Coyote banking trojan exploits Microsoft's UI Automation (UIA) framework to manipulate user interface elements and steal login credentials. The malware uses UIA's Component Object Model (COM) interfaces to evade traditional endpoint detection and response (EDR) tools, allowing it to extract sensitive data without direct process injection.

item.title: Ransomware Groups Weaponize RMM Tools to Infiltrate Networks and Exfiltrate Data
item.description: Ransomware gangs have co-opted Remote Monitoring and Management (RMM) tools to orchestrate sophisticated network intrusions, persistence, lateral movement, and data exfiltration. The tools were exploited by groups such as Hunters International and Medusa to evade traditional security controls due to their legitimate status.

item.title: CISA Alerts on Chinese Hackers Actively Exploiting SharePoint 0-Day
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft SharePoint; CVE(s): CVE-2025-49706, CVE-2025-49704; Summary: A vulnerability chain dubbed "ToolShell" is actively exploited by Chinese hackers to gain unauthorized access to on-premises SharePoint servers. The vulnerabilities allow for network spoofing and remote code execution, enabling attackers to achieve unauthenticated system access, authenticated access, and execute arbitrary code across networks.

item.title: Windows 11 Introduces Black Screen of Death and Auto Recovery
item.description: Microsoft has introduced significant updates to Windows 11's system recovery capabilities, including a redesigned "Black Screen of Death" interface and automated recovery features like Quick Machine Recovery (QMR) aimed at minimizing downtime and improving user experience during system failures. The new features promise to reduce system downtime and automate recovery processes, addressing critical pain points in enterprise environments.

item.title: Researchers Expose Russia’s Most Secretive FSB Spy Network
item.description: Researchers analyzed open-source intelligence (OSINT) and phaleristics to reveal the structure and operations of the Russian Federal Security Service's (FSB) 16th Center, a unit responsible for signals intelligence (SIGINT), cryptanalysis, and computer network operations (CNO). The study mapped the center's internal architecture, including at least ten departments, and geolocated ten SIGINT facilities across Russia.

item.title: Kali Linux Introduces Two New Tools for Raspberry Pi to Boost Wi-Fi Performance
item.description: The article is about the integration of Nexmon firmware-patching framework into Kali Linux, enabling native monitor-mode and packet-injection capabilities on Raspberry Pi boards. This update streamlines wireless security assessments on popular ARM-based Pi boards.

item.title: Chrome High-Severity Vulnerabilities Allow Hackers to Gain Full Control
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Google Chrome; CVE(s): None; Summary: The latest Chrome update addresses three significant security vulnerabilities, including two high-severity issues involving type confusion errors in V8, Chrome's JavaScript engine. These flaws can allow attackers to manipulate data types, leading to memory corruption and arbitrary code execution, enabling cybercriminals to bypass security measures, steal sensitive information, or install malicious software.

item.title: CISA Orders Urgent Patching After Chinese Hackers Exploit SharePoint Flaws in Live Attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft SharePoint; CVE(s): CVE-2025-49704, CVE-2025-49706; Summary: Two Microsoft SharePoint flaws, CVE-2025-49704 and CVE-2025-49706, have been added to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog by CISA due to active exploitation. The vulnerabilities, tracked as ToolShell, enable unauthorized access to on-premise SharePoint servers and are being exploited by Chinese hacking groups like Linen Typhoon and Violet Typhoon since July 7, 2025.

item.title: CISA Warns: SysAid Flaws Under Active Attack Enable Remote File Access and SSRF
item.description: Vulnerable Product: SysAid IT support software; CVE(s): CVE-2025-2775, CVE-2025-2776; Summary: Two XXE vulnerabilities, CVE-2025-2775 and CVE-2025-2776, allow for administrator account takeover, file read primitives, and potential remote code execution when chained with other flaws. The vulnerabilities were disclosed by watchTowr Labs researchers in May and addressed in SysAid's on-premise version 24.4.60 build 16 released in early March 2025.

item.title: Mozilla Launches Firefox 141 With Critical Security Fixes – Update Immediately
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Mozilla Firefox; CVE(s): CVE-2025-8027, CVE-2025-8028, CVE-2025-8034, CVE-2025-8035, CVE-2025-8040; Summary: The vulnerability summary states that Firefox 141 addresses 18 distinct CVEs, including high-impact memory safety bugs and moderate issues in URL handling and sandboxing. The most critical defects fixed include two high-severity flaws in the JavaScript engine, which could lead to arbitrary code execution, cross-origin data leaks, and privilege escalation.

item.title: Hackers Injected Malicious Firefox Packages in Arch Linux Repo
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Arch Linux; CVE(s): None; Summary: Three compromised packages containing Remote Access Trojan (RAT) malware were uploaded to the Arch User Repository (AUR), targeting users seeking alternative Firefox configurations and browsers. The malware was designed to establish persistent remote access capabilities on infected systems, potentially granting attackers comprehensive system access without user knowledge.

item.title: CISA Alerts on Active Exploitation of Microsoft SharePoint Code Injection and Authentication Vulnerabilities
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft SharePoint; CVE(s): CVE-2025-49706, CVE-2025-49704; Summary: Two critical vulnerabilities in Microsoft SharePoint allow attackers to gain unauthorized access and execute code, posing significant risks to enterprise deployments. The vulnerabilities can be chained together to create devastating attack scenarios, enabling malicious actors to view sensitive information and make unauthorized modifications.

item.title: Lumma infostealer malware returns after law enforcement disruption
item.description:
The Lumma infostealer malware operation has resumed activities after a massive law enforcement operation in May, which resulted in the seizure of 2,300 domains and parts of its infrastructure. Despite significant disruption, the operators claimed their central server had not been seized and restoration efforts were underway, eventually regaining trust within the cybercrime community.

item.title: Cloud Logging for Security and Beyond
item.description:
This article discusses the importance of cloud logging and monitoring in enterprise environments. It provides an overview of the different log categories for enterprise environments, including Audit, Compute, Network, Secrets, Cloud-Native Storage, and Kubernetes. The article also highlights the complexities of cloud logging across different cloud service providers (CSPs) such as AWS, Azure, and GCP.
The article emphasizes the need for a holistic approach to cloud logging that balances security, regulatory, and business needs while optimizing costs. It provides best practices for organizations to effectively monitor, secure, and manage their cloud environments.
Overall, this article aims to educate readers on the importance of cloud logging and monitoring in today's digital landscape.

item.title: EFF moves to stop power utility reporting suspected pot growers to cops
item.description: The article discusses how SMUD's smart meter data analysis program has been used to monitor and potentially identify individuals growing cannabis in their homes. Law enforcement agencies, including the Sacramento Police Department, have requested lists of customers using above a certain threshold of electricity, with disproportionately high penalties levied against Asian property owners who were found to be growing cannabis.

item.title: Windows 11 KB5062660 update brings new 'Windows Resilience' features
item.description:
FYSA:
This article discusses various updates and changes to Windows 11, including new features, fixes, and improvements. The main updates are:
1. Quick machine recovery: This feature enables automatic detection and fixing of widespread issues on Windows 11 devices using the Windows Recovery Environment (WinRE). 2. Streamlined interface during unexpected restarts: The updated design aligns with Windows 11's visual style and helps users return to work faster. 3. Boolean option for configuring Start menu pins: Administrators can apply Start menu pins once, allowing users to make changes to their pinned layout and have those changes safeguarded. 4. Improvements to Snap in Windows 11, including inline messages and keyboard shortcuts. 5. Fixes for various issues, such as authentication problems, file explorer bugs, graphics recognition, input method editor issues, stability problems, and Windows Firewall errors.
Overall, this article highlights the importance of keeping software up-to-date and secure, as well as the value of auto-recovery tools in mitigating downtime caused by widespread issues.

item.title: Windows 11 gets new Black Screen of Death, auto recovery tool
item.description: This article discusses Microsoft's Windows Resiliency Initiative, which aims to make Windows more stable and self-healing. The initiative includes the replacement of the Blue Screen of Death (BSOD) with a new Black Screen of Death, as well as the introduction of the Quick Machine Recovery feature, which can automatically resolve boot failures without requiring manual intervention.

item.title: Coyote malware abuses Windows accessibility framework for data theft
item.description: The article discusses a new variant of the banking trojan "Coyote" that abuses Microsoft's UI Automation framework (UIA) to identify which banking and cryptocurrency exchange sites are accessed on a device for potential credential theft. The malware, which targets 75 apps primarily in Brazil, uses UIA to extract web addresses from browser tabs or address bars and cross-referenced with a hardcoded list of targeted services.

item.title: CISA and FBI warn of escalating Interlock ransomware attacks
item.description: CISA and the FBI have warned of increased Interlock ransomware activity targeting businesses and critical infrastructure organizations in double extortion attacks. The advisory provides indicators of compromise (IOCs) collected during investigations, as well as mitigation measures to protect networks against this ransomware gang's attacks.

item.title: Major European healthcare network discloses security breach
item.description:
AMEOS Group suffered a security breach that may have exposed customer, employee, and partner information. External actors gained unauthorized access to its IT systems and accessed sensitive information.
Note: There is no specific vulnerability mentioned in the article, but rather a security breach at AMEOS Group.

item.title: Scavenger Malware Compromises Popular npm Packages to Target Developers
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Npm package eslint-config-prettier; CVE(s): None; Summary: The npm package eslint-config-prettier was compromised through a phishing email and used to distribute a novel malware dubbed "Scavenger" that targets Windows systems. The malware uses various evasion techniques, including anti-VM checks, anti-antivirus measures, and dynamic resolution of functions using CRC32 hashing.

item.title: Iranian Hackers Target Global Airlines to Steal Sensitive Data
item.description: APT39, a state-sponsored hacker collective connected to Iran's Ministry of Intelligence and Security (MOIS), was exposed as operating through the compromised internal systems of Amnban, a cybersecurity company. The breach reveals a sophisticated campaign involving cyber network exploitation (CNE) and preparation for cyber network attacks (CNA), with millions of airline passengers' sensitive personal identifiable information (PII) harvested worldwide.

item.title: Microsoft Links Ongoing SharePoint Exploits to Three Chinese Hacker Groups
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft SharePoint Server; CVE(s): CVE-2025-53771, CVE-2025-53770; Summary: The exploitation of security flaws in internet-facing SharePoint Server instances has been linked to two Chinese hacking groups, Linen Typhoon and Violet Typhoon, as well as a third China-based threat actor, Storm-2603. The vulnerabilities allow for authentication bypass and remote code execution, leading to the deployment of a web shell and potential data theft.

item.title: ETQ Reliance RCE Flaw Grants Full SYSTEM Access with a Single Space
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Hexagon ETQ's ETQ Reliance; CVE(s): 2025-34140, 2025-34141, 2025-34142, 2025-34143; Summary: The Java-based quality management system, ETQ Reliance, has several serious flaws including reflected cross-site scripting (XSS), XML External Entity (XXE) injection, authentication bypass, and remote code execution (RCE). These vulnerabilities were responsibly disclosed, leading to patches in NXG Release 2025.1.2.

item.title: ZDI-25-628: (Pwn2Own) Phoenix Contact CHARX SEC-3150 OCPP Authentication Bypass Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Phoenix Contact CHARX SEC-3150; CVE(s): CVE-2025-25271, ZDI-CAN-26346, ZDI-25-628; Summary: This vulnerability allows network-adjacent attackers to bypass authentication on affected installations of Phoenix Contact CHARX SEC-3150 devices. Authentication is not required to exploit this vulnerability, and an attacker can leverage it to bypass authentication on the system.

item.title: Threat Actors Target Linux SSH Servers to Deploy SVF Botnet
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Linux servers; CVE(s): None; Summary: Weak SSH credentials on Linux servers are being exploited by threat actors to launch DDoS attacks and cryptocurrency mining. The SVF Botnet malware is used to achieve this, which also incorporates proxy servers for enhanced evasion and has a modular design with customizable attack parameters.

item.title: Cisco: Maximum-severity ISE RCE flaws now exploited in attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Cisco Identity Services Engine (ISE); CVE(s): CVE-2025-20281, CVE-2025-20282, CVE-2025-20337; Summary: Three critical remote code execution vulnerabilities in Cisco ISE are being actively exploited. The flaws allow attackers to execute arbitrary commands as root without authentication and can lead to gaining a foothold on corporate networks.

item.title: What Is the Deep Web?
item.description: The article explains the concept of the "deep web", which refers to parts of the internet that search engines cannot index. It includes private databases, login-restricted content, and subscription-based pages. The deep web is legal, secure, and essential for daily online activity, supporting research, and powering secure access to sensitive systems.

item.title: New Web3 Phishing Scam Uses Fake AI Platforms to Steal Credentials
item.description: The article discusses a phishing campaign by the LARVA-208 threat actor group targeting Web3 developers. The attackers use spearphishing links to lure victims into downloading malware disguised as a Realtek HD Audio Driver, which executes PowerShell commands and exfiltrates sensitive data.

item.title: ClickFake Interview Attack Leverages ClickFix Technique to Deploy GolangGhost Malware
item.description: The article discusses the "ClickFake Interview" campaign by Lazarus Group, a North Korean state-sponsored hacker outfit. This operation targets job seekers in the cryptocurrency and technology sectors with fake job interviews that lead to malware deployment. The campaign uses the "ClickFix" technique, which exploits human vulnerabilities and bypasses traditional security measures.

item.title: UK Bans Public Sector from Paying Ransomware Gangs
item.description: The UK government has announced a comprehensive ban preventing public sector organizations from paying ransom demands to cybercriminals in an effort to disrupt the business model that makes ransomware attacks profitable. The ban aims to protect critical national infrastructure operators, including NHS trusts and schools, by prohibiting ransom payments to criminal groups.

item.title: Cisco Confirms Active Exploits Targeting ISE Flaws Enabling Unauthenticated Root Access
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Cisco ISE and ISE-PIC; CVE(s): CVE-2025-20281, CVE-2025-20337, CVE-2025-20282; Summary: A set of critical-rated vulnerabilities (CVSS scores: 10.0) in Cisco's Identity Services Engine (ISE) and ISE Passive Identity Connector (ISE-PIC) allows an unauthenticated, remote attacker to issue commands, execute arbitrary code, or upload and execute files as the root user. The flaws stem from insufficient validation of user-supplied input and lack of file validation checks.

item.title: UK to ban public sector orgs from paying ransomware gangs
item.description: The UK government is planning to ban public sector and critical infrastructure organizations from paying ransoms after ransomware attacks. The proposed legislation aims to target the business model that fuels cybercriminals' activities and makes vital services less attractive targets for ransomware groups.

item.title: Credential Theft and Remote Access Surge as AllaKore, PureRAT, and Hijack Loader Proliferate
item.description: This article discusses a long-running campaign targeting Mexican organizations with modified versions of AllaKore RAT and SystemBC. The attacks use phishing or drive-by compromises to distribute booby-trapped ZIP archives, which facilitate the deployment of AllaKore RAT.

item.title: Cisco Alerts on ISE RCE Vulnerability Actively Exploited
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Cisco ISE and ISE-PIC; CVE(s): CVE-2025-20281, CVE-2025-20282, CVE-2025-20337; Summary: A set of critical remote code execution (RCE) vulnerabilities affecting Cisco's Identity Services Engine (ISE) and Passive Identity Connector (ISE-PIC) products are being actively exploited in the wild. The flaws allow unauthenticated attackers to gain root-level access to vulnerable systems with a CVSS base score of 10.0, and no viable workarounds exist.

item.description: Vulnerable Product: Various (CrushFTP, Google Chromium ANGLE and GPU, SysAid On-Prem); CVE(s): CVE-2025-54309, CVE-2025-6558, CVE-2025-2776, CVE-2025-2775; Summary: Four new vulnerabilities have been added to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog due to active exploitation. item.title: DuraComm DP-10iN-100-MU
